merit.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: an advantage or good feature of something
merit.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Each of these approaches to teaching has its merits.
Tonight’s meeting will weigh up the relative merits of the two candidates.
The film has the merit of being short.
The merit of the report is its realistic assessment of the changes required.
The great merit of the project is its flexibility and low cost.
merit.translation[0].definitions[0].note: Merit is used especially in formal contexts. In everyday English, people usually talk about the good points of something:
The book does have its good points.
merit.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a good quality that makes someone or something deserve praise
merit.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: There is never any merit in being second best.
a film lacking any artistic merit
Students are selected solely on merit  (=because they are good).
merit.translation[0].note_box[0].section: They were discussing the merits of sending soldiers to the area.
The committee is considering the merits of the proposal.
Has any study assessed the merits of the two schools?
People began to question the merits of nuclear energy.
I can see no merit in violence.
What are the artistic merits of this statue?
There was no literary merit in his poems.
It seems to me that the idea has great merit.
The prize is given to students of outstanding merit.
There is considerable merit in using this kind of approach.
She is an expert in the relative merits of spa waters.
merit.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to be good, important, or serious enough for praise or attention
merit.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The results have been encouraging enough to merit further investigation.
It’s a fascinating book which merits attention.
merit.translation[1].definitions[0].note: Merit is not used in the progressive You say
This suggestion is meriting serious consideration
